  .topHead {
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 0;
    position: relative;
    width: 980px;

  .topHead h1 {

  }

  .topHead h1 a:hover {
    text-decoration: none !important;

    height: 44px;

  }

  }

    border-top: 0 !important;
    display: block;
    font: 10px Arial, sans-serif;

    position: absolute;
    right: 342px;
    text-align: left;
    top: 8px;
    width: 70px;

    color: #000;
    display: block;
    font: bold 10px Arial, sans-serif;
    padding: 1px 0 5px 65px;

  }

    padding: 0;
  }

  .subscribe a:hover {
    color: #2881B3;
  }

  .subscribe a:after {
    content: " \00BB";
    font-size: 11px;
  }

  .subscribe a:nth-of-type(1):after {

  .subscribe a span {
    display: none;

    display: block;
    height: 62px;
    left: 10px;
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 0;
    position: absolute;
    top: -12px;
    width: 48px;
  }

  .nav2 {
    border-bottom: 1px solid #BBB;
    border-top: 1px solid #000;
    display: block;
    margin: 0 auto;
    position: relative;
    width: 980px;
  }

  .nav2 a {
    background-position: 10px center;
    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-size: auto 16px;
    color: transparent;
    display: inline-block;
    margin: 0;
    padding: 8px 38px 8px 0;
    position: relative;
    text-decoration: none;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    white-space: nowrap;
    z-index: 10;
  }

  .nav2 section {
    background: #FFF;
    border: 1px solid #BBB;
    border-top: 1px solid #f1f1f1;
    font: 13px Arial, sans-serif;
    left: 300px;
    opacity: 0;
    padding: 10px 8px 10px 15px;
    position: absolute;
    top: -1000px;
    width: 240px;
  }

  .nav2 .mNews { left: 46px; }
  .nav2 .mEntertainment { left: 203px; }
  .nav2 .mFashion { left: 363px; }
  .nav2 .mRestaurants { left: 469px; }
  .nav2 .mBars { left: 615px; }
  .nav2 .mStores { left: 698px; }
  .nav2 .mMagazine { left: 683px; }

  .nav2 section a {
    border-top: 1px solid #F1F1F1;
    color: #000;
    clear: both;
    display: block;
    padding: 10px 0;
    text-transform: none;
    z-index: 9;
  }

  .nav2 section a:hover {
    color: #2881B3;
  }

  .nav2 a:hover + section, .nav2 a + section:hover {
    opacity: 1;
    top: 32px;
    transition: top 0.01s 0.3s, opacity 0.15s 0.32s;
    z-index: 2147483647;
  }

  .nav2 section a:first-child {
    border-top: none;
    font-weight: bold;
  }

  .nav2 .searchDiv {
    background: #FFF;
    border-left: 1px solid #BBB;
    display: block;
    height: 32px;
    overflow: hidden;
    position: absolute;
    right: 0;
    transition: width .5s;
    top: 0;
    width: 32px;

  .nav2 .searchDiv:hover,
  .nav2 .searchDiv.focus {
    width: 182px;
  }

  .nav2 .searchButton {
    background: #FFF;
    background-image: url(data:image/png;base64,);

    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-size: 15px 15px;

    cursor: pointer;
    position: absolute;
    right: 0;
    width: 32px;
    z-index: 10;
  }

    z-index: 10;
  }

  .nav2 .searchDiv .searchInput:focus {
    outline: none;
  }

						', NEST+m: An Allegory', 
							', The \u201cStuyvesant of the East\u201d has become one of the most sought-after public schools in the city. It got that way by leaving much of the public out. ', 
							', 
    ', 
				', 
    ', 
', 


							
						
						', 



', By ', Jeff Coplon', 
', 






',  Published Oct 24, 2007 ', 

						', 

						', ShareThis', 	
', 
	$("#ck_sharethis_top").attr("st_title",document.getElementsByName('Headline')[0].content).attr("st_url",document.location.href.replace(/\/index\d\.html/,"/"));
', 

						',  ', 


						', 


  
	', 
', 
', Car-service drop-off outside NEST+m', (Photo: Alex Tehrani)', 
', 
', 
', 


  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', A', s light faded on the first arctic day of winter, a band of 40 die-hard parents huddled on Seventh Avenue, outside Region 9 headquarters of the Department of Education. Mostly white and middle-aged, armed with signs and certainty, they stood shivah for a dream foreclosed on the Lower East Side: the notorious NEST+m, a school for the best and brightest in all New York.', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', Braced against the slicing wind, they chanted against the ousting of their founding principal, the feared and revered Celenia Chvere, and grieved for the motto she once posted outside her office door: ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', A public school with a private-school mission.', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', The sign dripped with hubris, but it had wooed the striving classes well. Since the troubled birth of New Explorations Into Science, Technology & Math, in 2001, its parents had tithed body and soul and disposable income\u2014for their children, to be sure, but also for the urban impossibility: a truly great public school. In NEST they\u2019d found a hothouse with record test scores, free of the usual tawdry concessions\u2014sardined classes, peeling paint, creeping illiteracy. ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', Now, after some nasty infighting and a crackdown by the chancellor, their school had been turned inside-out. For the old guard, everything precious seemed dead: small-group advisories, split-gender math and science, the Sarah Lawrence\u2013size seminars, the prepster dress code. Demoralized, the stalwarts had coined a different sort of slogan: ', Just another DoE school.',  ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', When a school loses the culture that made it distinctive, \u201cpeople imply that it\u2019s a law of history \u2026 that it died a natural death,\u201d says Deborah Meier, founder of the seminal alternative school Central Park East. \u201cIf we actually track it back, it may have been murdered.\u201d ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', Last fall, as NEST imploded, its PTA president emeritus moved her son to a private high school. \u201cI feel like I\u2019ve been robbed,\u201d says Emily Armstrong, \u201cand there\u2019s nothing I can do about it.\u201d She has a theory about why NEST\u2019s enemies sought to strangle it in the cradle and kept at it till they won. ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', \u201cIt\u2019s all race and class,\u201d she says wearily. \u201cIt\u2019s nothing else but that.\u201d', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', This is more than the story of a renegade educator or a bold experiment come undone. It\u2019s about the push-and-pull between excellence and access\u2014and about the unlucky children who get trampled along the way. Who owns the city\u2019s schools? Was NEST a beacon of meritocracy, or an island of privilege that barred students who needed it most?', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', \u201cNEST,\u201d says Granville Leo Stevens, of the Independent Parent Organizations, \u201cis an allegory.\u201d ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', NEST was designed to help solve an age-old dilemma: how to keep what was left of the city\u2019s middle class\u2014with its skilled progeny and open checkbooks\u2014inside a school system seen as second-rate. Without moneyed white people, went the presumption, the schools would flatline into irrevocable failure. The classic strategy was to keep funneling the most resources and best teachers to zoned schools in predominantly white areas. In mixed or changing neighborhoods, more of a sanctuary was needed: the gifted program. ', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', In 2000, Chancellor Harold Levy hit upon another approach. Taking a page from the private model, Levy imagined a constellation of \u201crigorous\u201d schools spanning kindergarten through twelfth grade, one for each borough. A K-12 would finesse the system\u2019s weakest link: the stand-alone middle school, a torture chamber that sends many a middle-class family heading for the exits. NEST would be the chancellor\u2019s prototype. He placed it in Community School District 1, a compact trapezoid in the Lower East Side and East Village that for years had bled its best students to District 2, its richer neighbor. Levy aimed to lure those families back with an innovative school to rival anything uptown.', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', The chancellor knew that his brainchild would need a lightning rod, a leader driven and unyielding. He chose Celenia Chvere, a petite firebrand with boundless energy, a blinding smile, and a hair-trigger temper. From her start as a lowly teacher\u2019s assistant in the late seventies, she\u2019d become one of the most coveted\u2014and controversial\u2014principals around.', 

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  

  


  

  

  

  



  

  
	', After raising two daughters as a single mother (enrolling the younger one, at great sacrifice, at Calhoun), Chvere knew the value of a superior public school. In 1986, when a freestanding gifted program sounded radical, she founded Lower Laboratory in District 2. Ten years later, on East 106th Street, she opened the Young Women\u2019s Leadership School, an oasis of Oriental carpets and nunnery quiet against the raging picket lines of now and the NYCLU. Yet despite her brilliance as a \u201cstarter,\u201d Chvere never stayed in one place too long. She ran a building like Hubie Brown coached a basketball team, with an overbearing manner that soon wore thin. \u201cIf you did not conform,\u201d says a source who worked with her in East Harlem, \u201cshe would destroy you.\u201d',

    var _sf_async_config={};
    /** CONFIGURATION START **/
    _sf_async_config.uid = 19989;
    _sf_async_config.domain = 'nymag.com';
    _sf_async_config.sections = "";
    _sf_async_config.useCanonical = true;
        
    var doc_type = document.getElementsByName("document_type");
    doc_type = doc_type.length ? doc_type[0] : "";
    
    var path = window.location.pathname;
    
    if( doc_type == "Article" ){
      
        _sf_async_config.sections = "Magazine";
        
    } else if( doc_type == "Listing" ){
      
        _sf_async_config.sections = "Listings";
        
    } else if( ( path.match("daily") && path.match("intel") || path.match("intelligencer") ) || path.match("politics") || path.match("news") ) {
          
        _sf_async_config.sections = "Daily Intel & News";
        
    } else if( ( path.match("daily") && path.match("movies") ) || nymag.dcads.levels.l1=="tv" ) {
                 
        _sf_async_config.sections = "Vulture & Entertainment";
        
    } else if( path.match("daily") && path.match("sports") ) {
      
        _sf_async_config.sections = "Sports";
        
    } else if( ( path.match("daily") && path.match("fashion") ) || path.match("fashion") || (false) ) {
      
        _sf_async_config.sections = "The Cut & Fashion";
        
    }

    _sf_async_config.authors = document.getElementsByName("Byline").length ? nym.trim(document.getElementsByName("Byline")[0].content) : "";
    _sf_async_config.authors = document.getElementsByName("author").length ? nym.trim(document.getElementsByName("author")[0].content) : _sf_async_config.authors;
    _sf_async_config.authors = document.getElementsByName("content.author").length ? nym.trim(document.getElementsByName("content.author")[0].content) : _sf_async_config.authors;

    /** CONFIGURATION END **/
    (function(){
      function loadChartbeat() {
        window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime();
        var e = document.createElement('script');
        e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript');
        e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
        e.setAttribute('src', (('https:' == document.location.protocol) ? 'https://a248.e.akamai.net/chartbeat.download.akamai.com/102508/' : 'http://static.chartbeat.com/') + 'js/chartbeat.js');
        document.body.appendChild(e);
      }
      var oldonload = window.onload;
      window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
         loadChartbeat : function() { oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); };
    })();
